title: Rate of Mass Loss of Calcium Carbonate

content.question:
<math alttext="H C l, aqueous, plus, C a C O 3, solid, react to produce, C a C l 2, aqueous, plus, C O 2, gas, plus, H 2 O, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

The reaction between <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the equation above. Two separate trials were carried out using <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> samples of the same mass, but one sample was a single piece of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and one sample was composed of small pieces of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The loss of mass of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time for both trials is shown in the graph below.

Which of the curves, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, represents the reaction with small pieces of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: Curve <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it shows that the reaction proceeded at a uniform rate.

Curve <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it takes a shorter time for the reaction to go to completion due to the larger surface area of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Curve <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it shows that the reaction proceeded at a nonuniform rate.

Curve <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it takes a shorter time for the reaction to go to completion due to the larger surface area of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Curve <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it takes a shorter time for the reaction to go to completion due to the larger surface area of <math alttext="C a C O 3, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 6.F: Explain the connection between experimental results and chemical concepts, processes, or theories.
